As’vagho·π£a is doubtless simple and practically shorn of artificiality in style. But while he would freely employ like Bha·π≠·π≠i alliteration and verbs in ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç, ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç and desiderative, K√°lid√°sa36 is sparse in his use of these little tricks and gives no evidence of deflecting the spontaneous flow of his style in such forced channels.

Pu·π£ply)amitra, Agnimitra and Vasumitra.

In Ma’la’, mention is made of historical persons such as Pu·π£pamitra, Agnimitra, and Vasumitra. In 185, B. C. Pu·π£pamitra, the General of the Maurya Kings37 slew his master Brihadratha, usurped his throne and founded what is known as the Sunga dynasty which lasted till 73. B. C. He was a great ruler, conquered several countries and had a tough struggle with the Greeks under Menander. His son Angnimitra was made the Governor of Vidis’ƒÅ, capital of ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£38 Pu·π£pamitra performed the famous horse-sacrifice (‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß) and the duty of guarding the horse was entrusted to Agnimitra’s son, who discharged it successfully and well by vanquishing certain Yavana troops who had ventured to challenge him. “The performance of the solemn rite probably was witnessed”, says Dr. Smith, “by the celebrated grammarian Pata√±jali, who alludes to the event in terms which imply that it occurred in his time.” From the mention of these persons and the close resemblance of the above facts with the horse-sacrifice of Dilƒ´pa and the conquests of Raghu, one would like to believe that KƒÅlidƒÅsa was contemporary of those persons. From the peculiar form of the Bharata-va’kya of the *Ma’la’*¬π, the learned Commentator Ki·π≠ayavema opines that the play was written and staged during the reign of the King Agnimitra or, in other words

_____________________________________________________________

1**.** ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É‡•§‡§Ü‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡•§

_____________________________________________________________

Kalidasa was his court poet¬π. Again, the concluding phrase, of the ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø, viz., ‘‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á’ being in the locative (nominative absolute) argues the present existence of a ruler named Agnimitra. Besides, the opening ≈õloka of the same play¬≤ conveys indirectly the same impression. There is presumably a pun on the word ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç and the suggestion is clear that the dramatist intends to make a departure from the well-known principle of ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç and introduces a reigning monarch as the hero of his play instead of some personality from past history. All this supported by the Bhita Medallion makes out an irresistable case for the orthodox theory.

The Play

Like the two other greatest Indian poets, viz., S’rƒ´ Har·π£a39 and Bhavabh≈´ti40, KƒÅlidƒÅsa wrote only three dramas41 of which Abhij√±a’na-S’akuntalam is a love drama and belongs to that class of ‘R≈´paka’ which is known as ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•§

Source of the play.

It is based on the well-known story of Du·π£yanta and S’akuntalƒÅ, as is told in the ƒÄdiparva of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (ch. 67-74), a succint survey of which is given below.

The story of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

Dusyanta, king of Prati·π£·π≠ha’na and scion of the lunar dynasty, in course of his hunting excursion came to the hermitage of Ka·πáva who was at that time out for gathering fruits; but his adopted daughter S’akuntalƒÅ, alone in the cottage, hospitably received him. At the sight of her, the king was smitten with

_____________________________________________________________

1. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚ÄîK.

2.

‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§º‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡••

_____________________________________________________________

love and asked her about her parentage, whereupon she herself made a clean breast of all about her birth-story. Knowing her to be a king’s daughter, the king without any further ceremony asked for her hand in marriage. The king promising to appoint her son his successor, she gave consent and was consequently wedded according to the GƒÅndharva form of marriage. The king apprehending the sage’s anger42, as permission had not been sought from him, very soon left the hermitage.

A little after, the sage returned to the cottage and divining what had transpired in his absence gratulated S’akuntalƒÅ on her choice43. The king when he returned to his capital dared not send for S’akuntalƒÅ, being afraid of the sage’s anger44. In the meantime S’akuntalƒÅ who was enceinte gave birth, at the end of three years, to a son, who even at the age of six years became very turbulent and harassed the wild beasts and consequently he was named “Sarvadamana.”45 At this time the sage thought it high time for him to go to his father’s place and be duly installed as YuvarƒÅja (heir-apparent)46. Consequently ≈öakuntalƒÅ with Sarvadamana being escorted by some disciples went to the king’s place. The king remembering every thing, yet perhaps, through fear of public calumny denied having any connexion with her¬π. At that critical juncture an aerial voice corroborated the statement made by S’akuntal√¢ and enjoined the king to welcome her as his legal wife. Then the king received S’akuntalƒÅ, made her the chief queen and Sarvadamana became the YuvarƒÅja. Such a simple and unromantic story is certainly suited to that oldest time when the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata was written, for its author merely intended to relate a bit of past history and he did it in a dry and unostentatious way. But our poet like Shakespeare who rarely originated the main plot of his dramas, handled this prosaic story of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata so ingeniously and with such innovations that the dry skeletons of the MahƒÅ-

______________________________________________________________

1**.**‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡•• ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡••‡•®‡•Ø‚Äî‡•®‡•¶‡••

______________________________________________________________

bhƒÅrata story have been, as it were, filled with flesh and breath and vitalised for ever.

Deviation from the Original.

Even at the outset we have ample instance of his foresightedness. In the original, the king in course of his hunting excursions, accompanied by his big army, minister and hierophant47 came to the hermitage of Ka·πáva and he at once entered it and kept the whole party waiting outside all the while he talked with S’akuntalƒÅ and married her,‚Äîas their presence might hamper the further progress of the plot. In Sa’kuntala’, however, the entrance of the king is perfectly natural. The king while keenly pursuing a deer outstripped his retinues and came to the said hermitage. This straying away of the king from his army has been utilised by our poet in depicting a dramatic finis of the first act, for the retinues not finding the king, rummaged the whole forest, entered the hermitage of Ka·πáva and made a great row while the king was deeply absorbed in conversing with S’akuntalƒÅ and her friends. The king perhaps liked to prolong his conversation ad infinitum, but there was a call from his higher duty of succouring the distressed and though unwilling he at once left them only to remove the chaotic condition of the hermitage and thus to pacify the denizens of the penancewood48.

Again in the original S’akuntalƒÅ received her guest, exchanged words with the king and herself gave a detailed account of her parentage49. Her nature thus depicted smells a bit coquettish. But our poet, who certainly possessed the faculty of imagination in a higher degree. felt the necessity of some companions for dramatic action and thus created the two sweet innocent disinterested friends in the form of Anas≈´yƒÅ and PriyamvadƒÅ, the conversation with the king being carried on through these friends. Even a superficial reader cannot but be amazed with the dramatic ingenuity which is manifested in the

method in which the said conversation with occasional jokes was carried on. Again, S’akuntalƒÅ’s love for the king at the first sight, her surprise at the change of her feeling antagonistic to penance-life and her bashfulness have also been delightfully depicted. The king’s amazement at the beauty of S’akuntalƒÅ, the gradual disclosure of his passion for the girl, his dramatic approach near the two, when S’akuntalƒÅ was attacked by a bee, have also been so been artistically delineated.

In the original as soon as the king became aware of S’akuntalƒÅ’s parentage, he proposed to marry her50. She however requested the king to wait a few minutes till her father who had gone out to gather fruits, would come back51. Our poet however considering a few hours to be too small a space of time to persuade a girl, quite ignorant of love affairs, to consent to marry a novus homo, deliberately made Ka·πáva absent from the field of play for several months on a pilgrimage to Soma-tƒ´rtha. This transmutation of Ka·πáva’s absence for a few minutes into several months is also a clear sign of our poet’s foresight, for it prolongs the king’s stay in the hermitage to protect the sacrifices of the ascetics disturbed by the malignants and thus enables the king to progress with his love affairs. Before solemnizing the GƒÅndharva marriage of the two haphazardly as is found in the original, our poet created the second and third acts with a view to depicting the gradual love-lorn conditions of our hero. With a view to breaking the dull monotony of the scene by some comic element and also to stopping the hunting excursion and devising some means for king’s progressing with the amorous affair with S’akuntalƒÅ, Vid≈´·π£aka. the jester-confidant of the king is introduced, though he has been wisely kept within his bounds and made to play a much smaller part in this drama than in the earlier works of KƒÅlidƒÅsa.

In the third act and its prologue, we have a vivid picture of the love-sick king, and S’akuntalƒÅ afflicted with love-malady. Even in such a stage her innate bashfulness, the conflict of emotions in her heart when confronted with two opposing duties and her modesty please us extremely. Unlike the original where the wedlock of the two were settled by this condition

that the son of S’akuntalƒÅ would be the possessor of the throne, our poet has dispensed with this sort of selfish bargain52.

In the original Ka·πáva though aware of the GƒÅndharva marriage and the pregnancy of S’akuntal√°, kept her in his hermitage for nine years and then made preparations for sending her to her husband’s place. S’akuntalƒÅ who seemed not to have any eagerness to meet her husband‚Äînay‚Äîwho was rather unwilling to leave the hermitage, thought that her hasty removal was due to the turbulent nature of his son who was disturbing the peace of the penance-grove53. Besides, a great incongruity prevails in the speech and action of the sage Ka·πáva, for there is no justification for what made him‚Äîan avower of the principle that a married woman should not stay for a long time in her relative’s house54‚Äîkeep S’akuntalƒÅ in the hermitage for such a long period. KƒÅlidƒÅsa, however, noticing all these incongruities, sent S’akuntalƒÅ the very day he was aware of the marriage¬π and also before her son was born. Obviously the king’s character is thus made to appear in a better light and a greater probability is given to the whole story. The parting scene of S’akuntala’ from the hermitage where she had resided so long and where every creeper and plant was bound by the tie of love and affection is poet’s all own.

In the fifth act or the public repudiation of S’akuntalƒÅ there is a greater deviation from the original. In the Maha’bha’rata the king deliberately feigns ignorance of the G√¢ndharva mariage and repudiates his forest-bride with abuses¬≤. KƒÅlidƒÅsa, however, with a view to absolve him from the moral responsibility in his rejection of S’akuntalƒÅ, ingeniously introduced the episode of DurbƒÅsƒÅ’s imprecation clouding the king’s memory. Certainly this is the greatest of all his innovations. “That there may be an ultimate recovery of memory, the curse is so modified as to

______________________________________________________________

1**.** ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî&c. Act IV.

  1. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§ø t ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§

______________________________________________________________

last only until the king shall see again the ring which he has given to his bride. To the Hindu, curse and modifications are matters of frequent occurrence; and KƒÅlidƒÅsa has so delicately managed the matter as not to shock even a modern and western reader with a feeling of strong improbability. Even to us it seems a natural part of the divine cloud that envelops the drama, in no way obscuring human passion, but rather giving to human passion an unwonted largeness and universality”.55

Durbasa’s cursedevelops love for flesh into commingling of souls.

We shall presently deal at length with the deeper meaning of this curse,‚Äîhow it rectifies S’akuntal√¢ by purifying her of the gross materialism of her love and how it ennobles the character of Du·π£yanta and develops an earthly love into divine love. Almost every line of Acts VI and VII save the idea of the turbulent nature of Sarva-damana, is original and is depicted in a masterly way56. Such is the charm and mastery of this concluding part of the play that even Bhavabh≈´ti in his masterpiece has found it worth his while to somewhat closely follow the model. In Uttara-ra’ma-carita SitƒÅ’s banishment and the pathetic wailing of her royal husband, the supernatural element, the scenic description, the surge of affection and yearning towards the unknown child of one’s own loins must have derived much of their pathos and splendour from the inspiration awakened by this portion of S’akuntala’.

The story of Padma-purƒÅ·πáa materially thesame.

The story given in the Padma-purƒÅ·πáa, Svarga-khanda, is almost exactly the same as it is found in the drama of S’akuntalƒÅ. Theking’s pursuing of a stag, importunities of the disciples of Ka·πáva not to kill the stag of the hermitage, the meeting of the king with S’akuntalƒÅ and her friends when they were watering the plants, Anas≈´yƒÅ’s description of the birth and parentage ofS’akuntalƒÅ, Du·π£yanta’s marriage with S’akuntalƒÅ according to the GƒÅndharva system, his presentation of his signet-ring to S’akuntalƒÅ, the imprecation of the choleric sage DurbƒÅsƒÅ, PriyamvadƒÅ’s propitiation of the sage DurbƒÅsƒÅ (Act IV.), Ka·πáva’s sending of S’akuntalƒÅ to her husband’s place accompanied by S’ƒÅradvata, S’ƒÅr·πÖgarava, and Gautamƒ´ &c. his address

to the denizens of the hermitage (Act IV), king’s astonishment at the sight of a beautiful woman in the midst of hermits and his non-recognition of S’akuntalƒÅ (Act V), the latter’s inability to produce the signet-ring, the priest’s proposal of keeping S’akuntalƒÅ in his own house until delivery, S’akuntalƒÅ’s removal by Menak√¢ in the shape of a light, while she bemoaning her ill-luck was following the priest to his house (Act V), the ring-episode where the token ring was found in possession of a fisherman who was bound on a charge of theft (Act VI ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï), king’s repentance at the sight of the ring, the story of the merchant Dhanamitra who died in a ship-wreck and one of whose wives was enceinte (Act VI), enhancement of king’s grief at the story of the aforesaid merchant and also at his own childlessness (Act VI.), Indra’s invitation of the king for chastising the disturbing DƒÅnavas (Act VI), reunion of Du·π£yanta with S’akuntalƒÅ and her son Sarvadamana who was tormenting a lion-cub in the hermitage of MƒÅrica (Act VII)‚Äîall these facts of the drama we find in the Padma-pura’·πáa, only a few of the Dramatis Person√¶ such as the Vid≈´·π£aka, Anas≈´y√¢, chamberlain, SƒÅnumatƒ´, portress are absent. We are astonished to find that scholars¬π are not rare even in India, who do not hesitate to opine that KƒÅlidƒÅsa drew his materials from the Padma-pur√°·πáa. This Pur√°·πáa is fraught with bigoted sectarianism and (like the Brahma-vaivarta PurƒÅ·πáa) contains the name of Ra’dha’, which is not only unknown in the Mah√¢bh√°rata, but also in such Vais·πáava works as Harivans’a, K≈´rma-PurƒÅ·πáa, Vish·πáu-PurƒÅ·πáa and Srƒ´mad-bhƒÅgabat. Certainly this book, at least as it has reached us in its present state, is of recent date. Even if we accept that the PurƒÅ·πáa kernel in it is very old, still the story of S’akuntalƒÅ in it is surely a later interpolation. This is corroborated by the fact that the ƒÄnandƒÅs’ram Edition of PP is bereft of ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•§Besides the story is very defective and so full of inconsistency that it cannot be accepted as having been composed by VyƒÅsa, the eminent writer of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. It is surely the production of some tyro who had both the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and our play

______________________________________________________________

1**.** PadmapurƒÅ·πáa and KƒÅlidƒÅsa by Prof Haradatta Sarma. Also Ra. I Ed. by Prof. B. B. GosvƒÅmi, also his S’akuntalam‚ÄîIntroduction.

______________________________________________________________

before him. This will be evident even from the language and idiom of the story of PP. The interpolator has, as already shown, closely followed the story of our poet. Only the absence of Ka·πáva for gathering fruits and S’akuntalƒÅ’s extraction of the promise from the king as to her son being made the prince, have been taken verbatim from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. Of the many defects of the story of the PP., we shall mention only a few which will disclose the capacity of the interpolator.

PriyamvadƒÅ in the Pura’·πáa plays animportant part. It is she who gave the king a detaileddescription of her friend’s birth, it is she who wasaware of DurbƒÅsƒÅ’s imprecation and its cessation with the presentation of some token of recognition. Again PriyamvadƒÅ according to the Pura’·πáa was allowed to accompany S’akuntal√° to the court of Du·π£yanta. The king, of course, could not recognise S’akuntalƒÅ owing to the sage’s curse, but the interpolator does not give any reason for king’s failure to recognise PriyamvadƒÅ. This is certainly awkward, for the imprecation affects S’akuntalƒÅ but it should have no effect on PriyamvadƒÅ. Besides as in the Maha’bha’rata, there is here even no insinuation that the king intentionally did not recognise PriyamvadƒÅ (and also S’akuntalƒÅ) for fear of public calumny. There is another glaring defect that PriyamvadƒÅ who knew every thing about the GƒÅndharva marriage, spoke not a single word on behalf of S’akuntalƒÅ. Again she was fully conscious of the loss of the ring¬π upon which depended the future of S’akuntalƒÅ, from her own hand in the water when S’akuntalƒÅ hadplaced it in her hand while performing her ablution, but it is very curious that she did neither herself search for the ring nor disclose the matter to her friend or to the sages. S’akuntalƒÅ also in a very strange way, after ablution, forgot clean to ask for the souvenir ring. Even a superficial reader will understand the unnaturalness of the

_____________________________________________________________

1**.** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡••

_____________________________________________________________

incident if he compares all these with the steps taken by the king Raghu to find out an amulet which by chance had slipped into the waters of Saray≈´57. Besides the author of the PurƒÅ·πáa in describing the story of RƒÅma followed not the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa but the Raghu-va·πÅs’am in its outlines. Sometimes he even paraphrases the wordings of KƒÅlidƒÅsa. This, we think, is sufficient to show that the story of S’akuntalƒÅ has been interpolated into the Pura’·πáa by a lesser writer of later date.

The Central Significance Of The Play

“Wouldst thou the young year’s blossoms
and the fruits of its decline.
And all by which the soul is charmed,
enraptured, feasted, fed.
Wouldst thou the earth and heaven itself
in one sole name combine ?
I name thee, O S’akuntalƒÅ ! and a‡••
at once is said”.58

‚ÄîSo says Woolf√§ng Von Goethe of Sa’kuntala’. The insight of Goethe told him what Sa’kuntala’ was‚Äînot merely patches of oriental romance, colourful, delicate, and gorgeous, strung round the central figure of a heroine, coy and delicate, beautiful and charming, but above all sweet and firm. Such undoubtedly S’akuntalƒÅ is‚Äîand indeed much more‚Äîa lily of our valley in all its bloom and beauty and freshness. Had she been merely “a creeper of the forest”‚Äîshe might have peers but she is more. She is not Miranda, the simple maiden nursed on a sea-girt isle in the company of enslaved nature-spirits like Ariel. She is an embodiment of love that purges itself of the wanton abandon of youth and ripens into the mature steadfastness and dignified bliss of love spiritual. Her life starts as all earthly lives in raptures and pangs, in forgetfulness of the beyond and immersion in the immediate and in a surrender to the senses. It is so far of the earth, earthy. But a little insight should warn you that she is not to stop here,‚Äîher birth and life

and training must carry her beyond these. And so her life opens up wide vistas and new,‚Äîarid deserts of nothingness and void when all the treacherous bloom and bliss fade away and depart, intense agony of a life first brought face to face with the unmasked reality of the earthly love‚Äîthen the emerging of the soul in its purity in the Abode of Bliss, in which it is calm, solemn like a prayer and dignified like a goddess. She has passed through the portals of fleshly pleasures to which human steps are bound, she has passed out of the deep and dismal shadow of desertion and dejection in which earthly love must end, and thus through austere tapasya’ of years and years she at last stands out under the full view of Heaven, as Love stands revealed only when desires have been conquered, earthly brilliance has been replaced by the effulgence of Heaven and the lover has known that the truest way of Love is through tapasya’.

≈öakuntalƒÅ’s life is destined by fate to be the battle-ground of this grand and noble passion. She is the daughter of a ·πö·π£i, but she has for her mother an Apsaras, and her birth has been She is her possible by a temporary lapse of the ascetic. mother’s child‚Äîhas the beauty and the grace and the gaiety of a heavenly nymph. But is she not truly and moretruly enough‚Äîthe daughter of a ·πö·π£i as well? That strain of asceticism, steadfast ardour for truth does she too share. And indeed in the hermitage of Ka·πáva, she has the happiest rearing up that could be desired for her.It is the hermitage of a householder-saint in which the womenfolk are the helpmates of their ascetic husbands, and Nature a true and loyal companion, where peace reigns supreme, flowers bloom in easy naturalness and the deer and other animals are, as it were, man’s next kith and kin. The girlhood of ≈öakuntalƒÅ is not hedged in with don’ts,‚Äîshe is not a child brought up in isolation and in ignorance of the world and its ways.To her the Navamallika’ is a sister, the young frolicking doe a playmate and at her approach the Kes’ara tree brightens up;‚Äîthese keynotes to her character are supplied by KƒÅlidƒÅsa himself in opening her story. But she is not to be a mere Miranda. She has for her companions Anas≈´yƒÅ and Priya·πÅvadƒÅ‚Äîhermitage girls no doubt but not unlettered in the delicate affaire de c≈ìur. To her they impart their knowledge as also all their sincerest friendship

of maiden days. So ≈öakuntalƒÅ has had a mind, simple and sincere, but she has been prepared also for being a joyful companion to her future husband, whoever the fortunate man may be. She is young, enjoys being so, as at the very outset we can see, and shares the glow and fervour of all young hearts. She has not been shut out from these natural human sentiments,‚Äîshe has never been taught that love is a forbidden fruit. She is not a hot-house growth nor is she a parasitical blossom. She has her roots deep in the soil she loves. And hence she has a longing for enjoying the supreme joy of a woman’s life, and a heart prepared in the natural environments of the hermitage for giving away the bliss without reserve. This proves to be her fall. She has not the shrewd business sense of the world to bargain when the beloved offers the cup of joy full. The spirit of bargain is foreign to her and the dictates of heart are too sacred to her to be questioned. She drinks it to the dregs without foresight and without fore-thought. To the god of love she is only a delicate doe and an easy victim‚Äîjust as the friends of her life, the deer of the hermitage, are to the gallant king. When she gives, she gives herself away full and complete, pays Love royally. This simplicity of heart, this noble sincerity leads her to her doom and to her salvation as well. Love that is forgetful of its own deep significance is too selfish to be happy. It does not widen the realm of the spirit, nay it narrows itself down to the bonds of flesh and thus calls down on itself the inexorable curse of flesh. Such was S’akuntalƒÅ’s love too‚Äîit did not lack decorum, it lacked poise; it had enough of fire but less of light. Hence it is that she loses that balance of her nature and the balance of her life. Look at the third act and prelude to the fourth act of the drama. It is the record of a soul cut away from the steady anchorage, tossed about by a stormy passion. It is the account of a love, however powerful, not great, for it is selfish and forgetful of the world, indeed, forgetful of its own sublime mission.

So the curse of DurbƒÅsƒÅ is not a mere accident, it is the nature of her love that calls it down on itself. It is fate’s decree, but her character is her own fate, as the poet has amply hinted. Yet it is her character again that will triumph overthe curse. Shadows hover round her, but she is all unconscious of the impending doom. Inspite of the riotous experience of

her heart she remains the simple hermitage girl, her soul still retains the unconscious message that it took in the ’tapovana’. The fourth act is a vindication of her own character and & vindication of the hermitage which has moulded it. The sage Ka·πáva, Gautamƒ´, the two girl mates, the deer, the creeper, all that has formed the back-ground of her life, appear in that great moment in their proper perspective‚Äîco-eval and co-equal with her very self. Men and women, animal and plant-lives all seem at this moment of inconceivable separation keenly alive to theloss they are going to sustain. The loss is not of one thing out of a number of things, but of a limb,‚Äîprobably of the very heart,‚Äîof a living organism. The pain of the separation quickens into an overpoweringconsciousness the severed, bleeding limbs of the tapovana. And the voiceless cry of her seems to pierce through the grief-laden atmosphere. The fourth act is KƒÅlidƒÅsa’s triumph in pure poetry as well as in dramatic technique, the irony of the situation making the pathetic farewell doubly so.

And the crash comes on the reader not at all suddenly. The opening verse of Ha·πÅsapadikƒÅ reminds one of the much too gay character of the king. Virtuous and noble he, nevertheless, confesses to a laxity and inconstancy in love, not uncommon among young princes in those days,‚Äî‡§∏‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§É‡•§ Here too, we are to note how DurbƒÅsƒÅ’s curse, as it affects Du·π£yanta, springs out of king’s own nature. The poet’s dramatic insight quickly glimpses the possibilities in the innovation of the curse of the cholerie sage. The projection of what is evil in nature out into the form of a foreign agent, while it preserves nature’s law and course, lessens much of its sickening criminality and saves the drama from sinking into absolute squalor. For S’akuntalƒÅ the curse is to lead to a spiritual re-awakening in which she is to go forward, for the king Du·π£yanta it is to effect a spiritual rebirth in which he should discover higher values of love and life.

The sixth act brings S’akuntalƒÅ’s disillusionment. It is the invariable tragic comment on the second and third acts. Curtain could easily have dropped here, if the poet had not to delineate a character like S’akuntalƒÅ. Western dramatists have given us heroines with such tragic endings. But KƒÅlidƒÅsa is different,

and her heroine has a different history and different character. She does not drag her heavy steps back to the old tapovana to lighten her heart in the groves of Nava-mallika’ or weep by the streams of Ma’linƒ´. The old place would not have been the proper background for this figure shrouded in unutterable grief. It must be full of reminiscences utterly out of tune with the present experience. Away, far away from the tumult of those stored impression in Ka·πáva’s hermitage, away from its crowd of innumerable associates of former joys and hopes and aspirations, she must fly to the very heart of blank solitude and in a fathomless stillness and silence, nurse her lonely riven heart all alone. The element in her character that has brought her dire and stark disillusionment sustains her through the transcending of her fate. The strong urge of love which led her to first youthful abandon now, sustains the soul in its next deeper strain when it makes for its calm, self-denying, austere career. Her noble origin and destiny she remembers in these times and she discovers that love to be true and never-failing must have its basis on a life of discipline and denial, that love must transcend the bonds of the senses. Her love has always been mighty, she longs to see it great. Only tapasya’ can make it so, her earthly charms wear away, gaiety is suppressed and is revealed in Act. VII at last invested with the dignity of a mother, calm, pure and holy as a steady flame. Her character is her salvation,‚Äîit is the salvation of Du·π£yanta too. The libertine is reborn in the world of Love‚Äîthat of courtly gallantry vanishes like a shadow in light. The seventh act is the story of the soul in travail‚Äîtill it is born worthy of the vision of a true Love worthy of S’akuntalƒÅ. Such is S’akuntalƒÅ‚Äîa soul’s pilgrimage from earthly delights to heavenly bliss, Love’s flowing into spiritual joy and epithalamium of Earth and Heaven.

Principal Characters In The Play.

**Du·π£yanta.‚Äî**The hero of the piece is Du·π£yanta, a scion of the illustrious line of Puru. KƒÅlidƒÅsa depicts him as an ideal man, an ideal king. In him we have a hero of the ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ type, and our poet has represented him as gifted with all those noble qualities which go to make such a hero, viz., generosity, self-restraint, fortitude, courage, modesty, amiability, righteousness and graceful bearing.

Young and handsome, the king is gifted with a physique which commands the admiration of all who come in contact with him. His charioteer finds in him a second PinƒÅkin, his general compares him to a mountain-roaming elephant unaffected by the stress and strain of the chase59 and Aditƒ´ is full of admiration for his well-built body60. Overflowing with youthful vigour he takes a keen interest in all pastimes which involve severe physical strain and hardship. With all his manly qualities, he is not lacking in those finer accomplishments which make a man charming and agreeable. Of sweet address and graceful bearing, Priya·πÅvadƒÅ finds in him a delightful companion and a pleasant talker61. He has a culture and refinement worthy of his position and takes a lively interest in such fine arts as music and painting. Natural sights and sounds have always a great fascination for him, and so keen are his powers of observation that even the minutest details cannot escape his notice62.

As a man he is an embodiment of all that is noble and divine in human nature. The pre-eminent traits of his character are his nobility of mind, his sense of honour and his wonderful self-control. And these come out prominently in his conduct towards S’akuntalƒÅ during their first meeting in the hermitage. Though fascinated by her youthful charms, he struggles hard to keep the unholy desire under control until he has ascertained her parentage and other facts relating to her. He is a dutiful and obedient son, and his tender regard for the feelings of his mother expresses itself in his solicitude when he receives a command from her to return to the capital, just after he has given his word to the hermits to protect them against the oppressions of the demons63. He is an ideal husband and a passionate lover. According to the custom of the times he had a large harem, and though his love towards S’akuntalƒÅ was essentially distinct from that shown towards his other wives, he was not unkind and never failed in his duties towards them64. He had great consideration for their feelings and did his best not to hurt them in any way either by deed or word. An incident in the sixth act admirably brings out this trait of the king’s character. Writhing in the agonies of remorse after the

cessation of DurvasƒÅ’s curse, the king tries to beguile himself a little by portraying his beloved on the canvas when he is informed of the approach of Queen Vasumatƒ´ and he removes the picture in great haste lest the same might offend her.65

As a king, he has a lofty sense of the duties and responsibilities of that exalted position. The paramount ruler of a vast country, he considers his kingdom as his household and looks after the welfare of his subjects with a fatherly tenderness and care. He is always ready to relieve the distressed and to protect the good against the oppressions of the wicked.He is a mighty monarch who holds the entire earth under his sway by his prowess, and the fact that even Indra, the king of gods, occasionally seeks his help bears testimony to his uncommon military genius. Though commanding respect and obedience from all classes of his subjects. he has the greatest reverence for Brahmins and ascetics. Hs is always anxious to see that their rites and practices are performed without let or hindrance and whenever any interruption or obstruction is apprehended, he is ready to protect them at all costs. So great is his regard for the hermits that at the very mention of the name he withdraws the arrow he was going to put to the bowstring and enters the hermitage in an humble attire and leaves his retinue outside lest he should disturb the tranquillity of the place and cause inconvenience to the inmates of the hermitage66.He is a just and upright ruler personally supervising the affairs of the state with a view to ensure the proper administration of justice. His decision with regard to the disposal of the deceased merchant’s property testifies to his strong sense of justice67. But nowhere are the strength of his character and his unflinching devotion to virtue brought out into such prominent relief as in his conduct towards S’akuntalƒÅ when, accompanied by Gautamƒ´ and the disciples of Ka·πáva, she appears at the king’s court as his wedded wife. Under the influence of DurvƒÅsƒÅ’s curse the king does not remember his marriage with her and conseqnently refuses to accept her inspite of the assurance given him by S’akuntalƒÅ herself and the disciples of Ka·πáva. Nothing can make him swerve even an inch from the path of virtue.

**S’akuntalƒÅ.‚Äî**In S’akuntalƒÅ, the heroine, we have a picture of an ideal woman. And the exquisiteness of the picture is to be found in the fact that S’akuntalƒÅ combines in herself physical charm with the beauty of the soul, passion with goodness, and virtue‚Äîin short, (in the words of Goethe) she “combines the young blossoms of the Spring with the ripe fruits of Autumn.” How admirably this combination of Heaven and Earth has been effected will become apparent if we compare the two contrasted pictures of the heroine presented by the poet at the beginning and at the end of the drama.S’akuntalƒÅ of the first act is a hermit’s daughter, full of youth, beauty and vivacity, “subtle and evasive, throbbing with love, veiled with reserve,” with “her two companions running over with playfulness, the newly flowering forest-creeper, the bee intoxicated with perfume and the fascinated king peeping from behind the trees.” At the end of the drama she appears as the image of patience and goodness; penitent and sober, invested with the dignity of a mother, clad in a dusty robe, her face pale with austerities and her soul purified by her long penance.

Born of a nymph-mother and a hermit father, S’akuntalƒÅ is possessed of a beauty that is not to be found among mortals68, a beauty that is quite natural and has nothing artificial about it. She looks exquisitely charming even in her simple garments. Like “a violet by a mossy stone half-hidden from the eye”, she dwells among hermits far away from the artificialities of town-life. Sweet and lovely as a flower, she is quite ignorant of the wiles of the world. Simplicity and purity are deep seated in her nature, and these were the direct outcome of her trustfulness‚Äîa virtue which was the cause at once of her downfall and her redemption. It was her trustfulness which allowed her to be carried away by the passion of love without the least suspicion, resulting in her humiliation and disgrace. It was again this trustfulness which sustained her through the most trying period of her life and kept her “constant to patience, forgiveness and loving kindness” and ultimately leads to her reunion with her lover. A daughter of Nature brought up in an atmosphere of freedom, she still presents a picture of feminine modesty and timidity. So great is her modesty that, though consumed by her passionate love for the king, she keeps

it concealed from her dearest friends. Her timidity and shyness are revealed in her conduct towards the king when left alone in his company69. The sweetest side of her character is her kind and affectionate nature. Brought up in the hermitage where peace and love reigned supreme, she had learnt to love the entire creation. Her heart is overflowing with the milk of human kindness which extends not merely to the animals in the hermitage, but also to the trees and creepers therein70. She regards them as her kith and kin and is interested in their joys and sorrows. She can not drink water without watering the trees and creepers; she never plucks a tender leaf even to decorate herself, and her joy knows no bounds when the trees first put forth their blossoms71. It is at the time of her departure for her husband’s place that her innate affection for every creature in the hermitage fully reveals itself. Though eager to meet her lover, she finds it difficult to tear herself away from the hermitage72. With a heavy heart she bids farewell to the trees and creepers of the hermitage and entrusts them to the care of her friends. She is anxious for the doe that has her confinement near at hand and asks her father to send her information of her safe delivery. When she starts from the hermitage, the motherless fawn whom she brought up with motherly tenderness does not leave her, and with tearful eyes she gently caresses it and persuades it to remain in the hermitage.73

A child of Nature, she is “obedient to Nature’s impulses like plants and flowers.” At the first outburst of passion on the occasion of the king’s visit, she could not restrain herself and allows herself to be carried away by it. Her love for the king is so absorbing that her lover became all the world to her and she forgets every thing except the loved one. With all the impetuosity of her passion, her sense of righteousness and femine dignity is remarkable. When Du·π£yanta repudiates his marriage with her and accuses her of falsehood, modesty and shyness give place to rage and indignation. She is an embodiment of the Hindu ideal of a woman. Despite her righteous indignation at the king for his disavowal of the marriage and her consequent humiliation, her affection for him

is not in the least diminished, and with a resignation characteristic of a Hindu wife, she blames her destiny, and not the king, for her miseries. The parting advice of her foster-father with regard to the duties of an ideal Hindu wife is firmly rooted in her mind and she tries to realise that ideal in her own life. Abandoned by her husband she leads a life of penance and rigid self-discipline and finally comes out of the trial in all her glory and purity.

**Ka·πáva‚Äî**Ka·πáva, the foster-father of S’akuntalƒÅ presents a perfect picture of a typical ascetic who combines divine vision wlth practical wisdom, rigid self-discipline with a susceptibility to the softer sentiments of the human nature. Underneath the calm and unruffled surface we find a strong under-current of human passion which reveals itself in the parental affection for his adopted daughter. It was an accident that he found S’akuntalƒÅ deserted by her parents and it was out of pity that he carried the helpless infant to his hermitage. Though he is thus only the foster father of S’akuntalƒÅ, his affection for her is genuine and real. He brings her up like his own daughter and is anxious to give her away in marriage to a husband worthy of her. It was out of his solicitude for her welfare that he was away from the hermitage on a pilgrimage to the sacred waters to pacify her evil stars at the time when the king visited the hermitage. On his return he learns with satisfaction the fact of S’akuntalƒÅ’s marriage with the king and like a true father immediately arranges to send her to her husband’s place. But nowhere is the intensity of his affection better revealed than at the time of S’akuntalƒÅ’s departure from the hermitage. With all his asceticism and self-control he finds it very difficult to part with S’akuntalƒÅ. The very thought of separation perturbs his mind, his heart is smitten with anguish. But his asceticism and self-control soon restore the equilibrium and throughout the rest of the pathetic scene we find him calm and collected and not overwhelmed with grief like any ordinary parent. Though leading the life of an ascetic far away from the turmoil of the world, he is not ignorant of the affairs of the world and has a clear grasp of the duties and responsibilities of a non-ascetic life74. His parting advice to S’akuntalƒÅ and his message to the king are wonderful specimens of worldly wisdom

and perfect knowledge of menand things. His advice to S’akuntalƒÅ is really “an excellent compendium of every wife’s duties” and portrays in an elegant and forceful language the Hindu ideal of womanhood. The message he delivers to the king through his disciples is another instance of his remarkable power. The whole message is couched in a language which is remarkable for its restrained and dignified tonewith due deference to the king as the lord of the earth.We have a last glimpse of the sage after the departure of S’akuntalƒÅ when consoling the weeping companions of S’akuntalƒÅ he enters the hermitage with a heavy heart, though not without an inward feeling of relief at the thought of having sent S’akuntalƒÅ to her husband75.

S’ƒÅr·πágarava and S’ƒÅradvata

S’ƒÅr·πÖgarava and S’ƒÅradvata are two of Ka·πáva’s disciples, and the fact that they are selected for the momentous task of escorting S’akuntal√° to her husband’s place shows that they occupied a position of pre eminence among the disciples76. Of the two again, S’√°r·πÖgarava seems to be the older and maturer in wisdom, because it is he who is placed at the head of the party and it is to him that Ka·πáva delivers the message for the king. The two disciples, however, differ widely in their disposition and temperament. S’ƒÅr·πÖgarava is haughty, conceited easily excitable and impatient of contradiction, while S’ƒÅradvata is sober, considerate and self-possessed. The former regards the ascetic life as the best and looks down upon other orders of life, while the latter, though realising the supremacy of the ascetic life, is full of consideration and sympathy for the life of the ordinary people. The sight of the king’s court creates different impressions in the minds of the two. S’ƒÅr·πÖgarava compares the place to a house which is in flames and should immediately be shunned, while S’ƒÅradvata pities the condition of the people there whom he regards as asleep and in fetters77.When the king fails to remember his marriage with S’akuntal√° and is in a state of hesitation, S’√°r·πÖgarava grows impatient and considers the king’s silence as an indication of the perversity born of power78. Again, when the king disbelieves the story of his marriage even

after the assurance given by the ascetics and S’akuntalƒÅ herself and expresses his inability to accept her as his wedded wife, his self-control gives way to indignation and wrath and he charges the king with meanness and insincerity79. S’√°radvata’s self-possession and practical wisdom save the situation all throughout. It is S’ƒÅradvata who suggests that S’akuntalƒÅ should speak for herself in order to convince the king of the marriage80. After the king’s repudiation of the marriage, when S’ƒÅr·πÖgarava indulges in a vehement expression of his wrath by uttering imprecation on the king for his meanness and insincerity and by rebuking S’akuntalƒÅ for her thoughtlessness, S’ƒÅradvata with his characteristic coolness, asks S’ƒÅr·πÖgarava to put a stop to that altercation and asks the party to depart leaving S’akuntalƒÅ whom the king as her husband and lord could accept or reject just as he liked.81

Anas≈´yƒÅ and Priya·πÅvadƒÅ

Anas≈´yƒÅ and Priya·πÅvadƒÅ, the two companions of S’akuntalƒÅ are “the best types of sincere sisterly affection.” They are of the same age as S’akuntalƒÅ, and their beauty is not much inferior to hers82. What endears them most to us is their disinterested and sincere attachment to S’akuntalƒÅ who is to them all in all, the centre of all their thoughts and anxieties. The sole aim of their existence seems to be nothing other than ministering to the happiness of their friend in every possible way. They help her in watering the plants and in looking after the trees and creepers of the hermitage entrusted to her care by her foster-father. Their anxiety at the state of her health when she is smitten with love which, out of modesty, she conceals from her friends, their importunate entreaties to her to reveal to them the cause of her affliction, their ingenious contrivance of the secret interview between their friend and her lover, themselves keeping guard over the meeting while the two lovers are engaged in delightful conversation‚Äîall these go to show their genuine affection for S’akuntalƒÅ. When they overhear the curse of DurvasƒÅ upon their friend who was oblivious of everything else in her overpowering passion for the king, their anxiety knows no

bounds and they do their level best to appease the sage and ward off the curse. Though they are eager to see their friend united with her lover, yet it is with great sorrow that they part with her and return to the hermitage which bereft of S’akuntalƒÅ, has now lost all its charms for them.

The two friends, however,form a contrasted pair. Priya·πÅvad√° is more vivacious, gay, saucy and quickwitted, while Anas≈´yƒÅ is more thoughtful and grave. Priya·πÅvadƒÅ is characterised by strong feeling and is prone to act on the impulse of the moment without bothering muchabout the future; while Anas≈´yƒÅ is characterised by maturer understanding and is very considerate and cautious and thinks more of the future than the present. The mutual attraction between S’akuntalƒÅ and Du·π£yanta ishailed with great joy by Priya·πÅvadƒÅ who tries to bring about a speedy union between the lovers to complete the happiness of their friend, while Anas≈´yƒÅ cares more for the future consequences of the union than the immediate happiness of S’akuntalƒÅ and tries to ascertain by clever talks with the king, the possibility of happiness resulting out of the union.When they overhear the curse of DurvƒÅsƒÅ, both are, no doubt, greatly shocked; but while Priya·πÅvadƒÅ is bewildered and at a loss to ascertain what to do, Anas≈´yƒÅ soon recovers self-possession and tries to think out the means of warding off the curse.

DRAMATIS PERSON√Ü

PERSONS SPOKEN OF.

‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï-‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•å ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã
‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ-‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡••

‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É‡•§
‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ö ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ã
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®-‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§-‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§µ-‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§•-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡§∞‡§≤-‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø-‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®-‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å-‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø-‡§∏‡•Å‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß-‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø-‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ß‡•Ä-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞-‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä-‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†-‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É
‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ß-‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§-‡§™‡§•‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø‡•§
‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§-‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ
‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ-‡§ï‡§£‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§É‡••

‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂-‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§
‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ-‡§∞‡§∏-‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§≠‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à-
‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§á‡§π ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞-‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø

‡••‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡••

‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®-‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç
<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1736598162Capture13.PNG"/>

‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä,
‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É,
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§É‡••‡•ß‡••(‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ)

The form that existed immediately before the creator (i.e., water) ; the form that conveys (to the gods) duly offered clarified butter (i.e., Fire); the form that is the sacrificer; the two forms that define time (i.e., the sun and the moon); the form that has sound for its property and pervades the universe (i.e. Ether) ; the form which is called the source of all created things (i.e. Earth); the form by which all that is living possesses strength (i.e. Air),‚Äîlet ≈öiva, known by these eight sensible forms, preserve you (all).

V. L.:‚Äî‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É’‚ÄîR. V. M. S. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É‚ÄîB. ‘‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§’‚ÄîM. S. K ‘‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú’‚ÄîR. V. B.

‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‘‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ω‡§Ω‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï-‡§µ‡§ö‡§®-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§à‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡••‘‡§Ø‡§æ’ ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§É’ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‘‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ’ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ; ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‚Äú‡§§‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å-‡§∏‡§Æ-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‚Äì‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É‚Äù‡•ß‡•§‡•Ø ‘‡§Ø‡§æ’ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ

‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ (‚Äò‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•å ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‚Äô‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä)‡•§ ‘‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‘‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§É’ ‡§ò‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‘‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø’ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É[‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§§‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç] ‘‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä’ ‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡•§ ‘‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á’ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä’‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É’ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§û‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‘‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É’ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§É (‚Äò‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§Ω‡§Ω‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É) ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‚Äò‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É’ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§É ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç (‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä) ‘‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É’ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É (‘‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á-‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ω‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä) ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‘‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ’ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ, ‘‡§Ø‡§æ’ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§É (‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‚Äù ‡•ß‡•§‡•≠‡•´, ‚Äò‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‚Äô‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç’‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ’ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‘‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç’‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ-‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç’ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç (‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§ú‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É)‡•§ ‘‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§π‡•Å‡§É’‡•§ ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É‡•§ (‘‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§É’ ‡•©‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•Æ‡•™ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‘‡§â‡§∏‡•ç’ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§Ω‡§Ω‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ)‡•§ ‘‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ’ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§É’ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§É(‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É) ‚Äò‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äô ‡§π‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É[‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§π‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§¨‡§≤‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§® ‡§™‡•å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§] ‘‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É’ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‘‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É’ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§É(‘‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§∂‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å) ‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É’ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§É’‡§à‡§∂‡§É’ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É (‘‡§à‡§∂‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡§æ ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä); ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî(‚Äú‡§ú‡§≤‡§Ç‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äì‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡§É‚Äù) ‚Äò‡§µ‡§É‚Äô‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‘‡§Ö‡§µ‡§§‡•Å’ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•Å [‡§è‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‘‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É’‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å’‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, ‘‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø’, ‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§ø’, ‘‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø’‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§õ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø‡•§ ‚Äò‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äô‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§Ç‡§¢‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‘‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç’‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§]

1n.‚Äî1. ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚ÄîUsually ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§É is explained (R.V.M.S.) as “of the creator” and ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É as “the first creation”. Thus the clause means “which is the first creation of the creator” i.e., water, and in support of this explanation ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•å‚Äô(MS. I. 8) has been invariably quoted. But this explanation has to be taken with a grain of salt, for nowhere in the scriptures water is said to be the first creation and any thing contradictory to the Vedas is invalid. Now ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•å of Manu means “before the creation of the golden egg (‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°) in which was born ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ, and not before the very beginning. Cf. “‡§Ö‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§π‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ”‚ÄîKB. Later on in S’lokas 75-79, Manu clearly states that of the five elements water was created after Fire, the order being ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂>‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å>‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø>‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç>‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä. This genesis of the creation is in consonance with that of the ≈öruti which states‚Äî‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‚ÄîTaittirƒ´ya Upani·π£at. Apparent anomalies like ‘‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§É ‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§’‚ÄîB·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka Upani·π£at; ‚Äú‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§É‚Äù‚Äî·πöV ; ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‚Äù‚Äî≈öatapatha BrƒÅhma·πáa XI. I. 6. I; ‘‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç’‚ÄîTaittirƒ´yaBrƒÅhma·πáa, have been reconciled by S’rƒ´≈öa·πÖkarƒÅc√°rya thus:‚Äî‘‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§É ‡§Ü‡§™‡§É ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§’ It is very difficult to believe that a versatile poet like K√°lid√°sa was unaware of the statements of the ≈öruti. So we propose to explain ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Éas referring to ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ and ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ as anterior, or immediately preceding.‚Äô Vide “‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äîimmmediately before the eleventh i. e., the tenth”‚ÄîM.’s Sanskrit-English Dictionary P. 137; “So ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É”‚ÄîAD. K√°li, has already used ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø in this sense. Cf.

‚Äú‡§è‡§ï‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§π‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‚Äù‚ÄîKU. VII. 44. ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç <MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1736681693Capture2.PNG"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1736681693Capture2.PNG"/> ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äö ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•å ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡•å ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å, ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚ÄîMN. ‚Äú‚Äîinterdum Vishnu prior est Sivas, Seu hoc Vishnu, Seu Brahman ambolus illis, Seu ambo illi Brahman"‚ÄîA. F. Stenzler’s (Ku.) If our explanation is accepted the whole will mean‚Äî(The form) i. e., water which was (immediately) anterior to the birth of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ i. e., ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ (who in the shape of a golden egg was born in water‚ÄîMS. I. 10). Here is ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ (apparent contradiction), for how can water a created thing exist before the creator, but the solution is that the water is the creation of ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ (‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç) and not of ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ (‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø)‡•§ ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§É’‚ÄîKPr.

2. ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø &c. ‚Äîrefers to fire, the carrier of oblations to the gods. Cf. ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É’, ‘‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡•Å’‚ÄîS’ruti; ‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•Å+‡§á‡§∏‡§ø (‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‚Äì‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø-‡§π‡•Å-‡§∏‡•É‡§™‡§ø-‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§∏‡§ø‡§É’, ‡§ä‚Äì273.)=‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§É anything thrown into fire. ‡§π‡•Å ‡§≤‡§ü‡•ç, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ; ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡•å‡§∑‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç, ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§µ, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ, ‡§∂‡§§‡•É ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•• 3. **‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç‚Äî**Cf. “‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç”‚ÄîRa. 1. 6. For the force of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø see Com. 4. ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‚Äî‡§π‡•Å+‡§§‡•É‡§ö‡•ç(‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§ö‡•å 3. 1.133)+‡§ô‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ô‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç,4. 1. 5.). During the performance of the sacrificial rites a sacrificer is regarded as a portion of S’iva. Cf.‚Äî‘‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•ã‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§∂ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç’‡••‚ÄîRa. III. 66. 5. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç &c.‚ÄîThe Moon has nothing to do in regulating the time (‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•á’‚ÄîMS. 1. 65), still K√°lid√°sa here follows the popular notion accord‚Äî

ing to which the sun regulates the day, while the moon regulates the night. 6. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‚Äîrefers to ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ which has only one property viz. sound. Excepting this and ‘‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É’‚ÄîRa. XIII. I, there is no reference to the Ny√°ya Philosophy in K√°lid√°sa’s work. Prof. Apte is of opinion that the poet might have borrowed the idea from the SƒÅ·πÖkhya Philosophy. Hence KƒÅlidƒÅsa might have lived before the development of the NyƒÅya Philosophy. Cf. ‘‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§∏‡•Ä’‚ÄîVik. I.; ‘‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø-‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§-‡§∞‡§µ-‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§É‚ÄîHS. 7. ‡§Ü‡§π‡•Å‡§É‚Äî‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å+‡§â‡§∏‡•ç (‡§≤‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø)‚Äîcf. ‘‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç’‚ÄîSPB. II, 57. ‘‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É’‚ÄîVik. I. 1 ; K√°li here refersto ‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø in support of the existence of God, against the scepticism of the Buddhists. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‚Äîrefers to the earth, cf. ‘‡§á‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç (The material cause of all created beings.) ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á’‚ÄîMS. IX. 37. In connection with ‡§á‡§§‡§ø, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø has become ‘‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§’ hence ‡•ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡•§ Cf. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç-‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‚Äú‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù‚ÄîSK. 537 ; ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‚ÄîKSV. V. 2. 22. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É‚Äù‚Äî258 n. 5. 8. ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§É (5. 2. 115) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É (8. 2. 9 )‚ÄîTo remove tautology, explain ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§É as “creatures that are born” and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£ as vital activity, energy. Cf. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1736682186Capture2.PNG"/> <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1736682186Capture2.PNG"/> ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§É‚ÄîMah√°. Dro·πáa. 31, 48. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á=‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§¨‡§≤‡•á‚ÄîNilakan·π≠ha. **‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ=**‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, hence ‘‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡•©‡§Ø‡§æ or say ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•å‡•©‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ 9. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‚Äî‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç’‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É &c.‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ÉVart. 2. 2. 18.

Or ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø means ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•§ Cf. “‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§É”‚ÄîJS. Hence ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ü‡§ö‡•ç comes in by GS. ‚Äò‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§É’ 5. 4. 107. Next ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§É, ‘‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç’ 5. 2. 127 ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡•§ Cf. ‚Äú‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‚Äù‚ÄîBD. 676. ‡§®‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ω consider ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ and ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å as ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø and not ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑. Ved√°ntins, however, hold that as ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ to the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø’s, so ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ may be considered as ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•§ ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ω consider ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å as ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ cf.‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Ç‚Äì‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‚ÄîMuktƒÅvali. 10. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É‚Äîis better than ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É(pleased) in which case, also when ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§® is explained as ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ (R), the epithet ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Éhas no force. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É means ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É, but in most cases ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É, Cf. ‘‡§∂‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç’‚ÄîGƒ´tƒÅII. 7. ‘‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶’‚ÄîCandƒ´. Here the second meaning seems to be suitable, for the inference of the existence of ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ is drawn from eight forms which are ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‚Äîby those wellknown forms hence ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•çis not necessary cf. ‚Äú‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù‚ÄîSD. VII. 11. **‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‚Äî**Cf. ‘‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§É ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É’‚ÄîYƒÅdava qtd. MN in Ra. II. 35; M√°l√°. I. I; KU. 1. 57; VI. 26; KP. X. 25; PP. V. 3. 94; VP. I. 88. 12. ‡§à‡§∂‡§É‚Äî‘‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É’‚ÄîAK. ‡§á‡§∂+‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø by ‡§á‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡§ß‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§É 3. 1. 135.

**Remark‚Äî**R opines that the subject-matter of the play is hinted at in the above ≈öloka (cf. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‚ÄîDR.) ‡§Ö‡§• ‚Äò‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äô‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ’ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‘‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç’ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç’‡§π‡§µ‡•Ä’ ‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§É‡•§ ‘‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‘‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‘‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç’ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç

‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É’ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‚Äò‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ-‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§-‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§-‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞-‡§¶‡•á‡§∂-‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç <MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1736682428Capture2.PNG"/> ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç‚Äî‡•§The metre ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ (‡§Æ, ‡§∞, ‡§≠, ‡§®, ‡§Ø, ‡§Ø, ‡§Ø ) in the ≈öloka suggests that the Drama will contain seven acts‚Äî‚Äú‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù‚ÄîR.

(‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á) ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É (‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø)‚Äî‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

(After the recitation of benediction), Stage-manager,‚Äî(Looking at the tiring room),‚ÄîGood Lady, if your tiring is finished, please come this way.

**‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‚Äî**‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî“‡§Ü‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ-‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§ú-‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï-‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§¶‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§§”‡•• ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§¶‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•á‚Äî‚Äú‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‚Äù‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É’‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É’ ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‘‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á’ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•á ; ‘‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç’ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‘‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É’ ‡§®‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ (‘‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§É) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî ‚Äú‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‚Äù‡§á‡§§‡§ø)‡•§ ‘‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§∞‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç ‘‡§Ö‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç (‚Äú‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•à‡§Æ‡§É) ‘‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§ (‚Äú‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äù‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç)‡•§ ‘‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç’ ‡§Æ‡§∑‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§É‚Äî(‚Äú‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø-‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§®‡§ü‡•á ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‚Äù)‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç’‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç’‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø’ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‘‡§á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç’ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•á’‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É‡•§
